Award.AwardTitle: Alkynes As High-Energy Carbon-Rich Functionality For Synthesis Of Polyaromatics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Igor Alabugin. Professor Alabugin is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the Florida State University. He is developing new ways to prepare precisely shaped and functionalized structures of graphene (a flat sheet containing only carbon atom). The goal of the project is to provide the missing synthetic tools needed to construct new molecules with interesting optoelectronic properties. To do this, the high energy and unique, tunable reactivity of carbon-rich precursors for will be used to develop strategies that build the shaped graphene structures from smaller pieces. Key to this effort are cascade reactions that form multiple bonds and unite multiple cyclic unites in a single operation. By splicing together the smaller structure in a controlled fashion, the shape of the larger object can be controlled more precisely. The results will be disseminated in the PI's publications and outreach activities, including participation in public lectures, scientific symposia, giving talks at industrial, undergraduate, and graduate institutions, as well as recording educational videos at the GEOSET studio at Florida State University.

The intellectual merit of this research is in leveraging electronic factors that control alkyne cyclizations for the development of efficient routes to conjugated carbon nanostructures with predesigned shape and functionality. In this approach, oilgoalkyne chains of varying sizes, equipped with different substituents, are built in a modular fashion and then "zipped" up via a cascade of fast and efficient radical cyclizations. Selectivity of initial radical attack on the multifunctional substrates is controlled by the presence of a "traceless directing group" that is removed in the course of the one-pot process. By the choice of the relay functional groups and the terminal pi-system, the final step of the cascade can be controlled, so that either a five- or a six-membered rings is formed. In particular, this work is developing a suite of peri-cyclizations based on a combination of traceless directing groups, cyclization at the "zigzag edge" of acene subunits, and fragmentations. This approach opens access to unusual aromatics and conjugated persistent radicals. The broader impact include the applications of the new carbon-rich conjugated molecules as components in the design of optoelectronic materials, energy storage devices, sensors, transistors, solar cells, polymer composites etc. The educational plan includes providing advanced research training to students of different backgrounds, including students from the Florida historically black universities. The scholarly findings will be presented in scientific journals, conferences and incorporated in the mini-courses on stereoelectronic effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal developed new approaches to the rapid construction of carbon nanostructures of precise dimensions and tunable structural, optical and electronic properties. These structures were created via efficient cascade transformations of modularly assembled alkyne-rich precursors.

The intellectual merit of this research is in leveraging electronic factors controlling alkyne cyclizations for the development of efficient routes to conjugated carbon nanostructures with predesigned shape and functionality. In our approach, functional molecules of varying sizes and shapes, equipped with the carbon-rich high-energy alkyne groups, are built in a modular fashion using well-characterized and reliable cross-coupling chemistry. In the key step, these systems are then zipped up via a cascade of fast and selective radical cyclizations. Selectivity of initial radical attack on the multifunctional substrates is controlled by the presence of traceless directing groups that are removed in the course of the one-pot process. By the choice of the relay functional groups, the final step of the cascade can be controlled.

By design the expanded carbon-rich polycyclic molecules can either contain a five-membered ring (?a defect?) or be made exclusively through the fusion of hexagons (?defect-free?). We have found the pentagonal ?defects?, in fact, provide unprecedented opportunities for injecting a negative charge without injecting spin into polyaromatics by using the acidic C-H bond at the pentagon. Such negatively charged nearly-planar ring systems can be used for the construction of supramolecular assemblies with the greater degree of structural control and the possibility of including positively charged inorganic structural elements.

For the defect-free polycyclic systems, we have developed a new type of cyclizations, i.e., the peri-cyclizations that allow fusion of additional benzene rings to the zigzag edge of existing carbon-rich aromatic systems. We were able to initiate two of such cascades on the same molecule, thus allowing two new rings to be added at the same core (i.e., double peri-cyclizations). Furthermore, as such cascades propagate from the edge to the center of molecular structure, they can also modify the central part, stitching it into a larger, more connected, core. All of that opens fast and convergent new synthetic approaches to useful molecular architectures.

Finally, we have invented a way to add the total of three new rings on top of a benzene ring incorporated into a variety of precursors. This transformation converts this benzene ring into a pyrene unit into a single synthetic operation. Such unprecedented reaction works by wrapping the new cycles around the perimeter of the central ring at three consecutive carbon atoms. It opened access to ring systems that have never been prepared before. We are in the process of further extending the scope of this unique transformation and exploring the electronic properties of such molecular systems.

The broader impact will be in the applications of the new carbon-rich conjugated molecules as unique components in the design of optoelectronic materials, energy storage devices, sensors, transistors, solar cells, polymer composites etc. This research will also lay the mechanistic, structural, and kinetic foundations for successful applications of alkynes in synthesis and materials science. The proposed research will enhance our understanding of the reactivity of both the alkyne moiety and radical species.

Furthermore, the theoretical and experimental components of this work contributed to training of specialists in several areas of chemistry and provided researchers at the undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels with an opportunity to integrate learning and discovery. The results have been disseminated in the PI?s publications and outreach activities, including 57 lectures at scientific symposia, undergraduate colleges, and research universities.


Last Modified: 07/02/2021
Modified by: Igor Alabugin
